Being young, he sorely missed his family's support. He got involved with people of dubious character and began drinking, wasting most of the money he earned. 

Now he has reconsidered and changed this situation because he knows he has to take care of himself. He works hard so that he can save and be able to buy his own things. He found out about Kiva loans. Wishing to find another income source as a motor taxi driver, he is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike so that he can earn more income and save for whatever the future holds.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike so that he can offer taxi service.

loans.name: Ayman

texts.en:
Ayman is a 33-year-old single man. He has worked in selling hunting weapons, cartridges, and many other related items since 2010. 

This business is important to many hunters, especially in this period of the year, since all the hunters have to prepare themselves for the coming bird hunting season.

Ayman has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to increase his business merchandise with special hunting cartridges for the coming hunting season.

Ayman has been Al Majmoua borrower for two consecutive cycles.  His previous loan improved his business a lot, and expanded his product sectors.

He hopes to expand his business as much as he can to cover hunting activities and everything a hunter could need.

loans.use: To increase his business merchandise with special hunting cartridges for the coming hunting season

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon, a 61-year-old businessman, is married to Elizabeth, a farmer. They are blessed with three children aged 16, 15 and 10 years old. Solomon has operated a livestock trading business for the past twelve years with a monthly income of KES 12,900, which he uses to support his family. 

Solomon is applying for his first loan with KADET LTD, having been introduced to KADET by a staff member. He will use the loan to buy more goats and sheep for selling. Solomon will use the anticipated profit from the business to educate his children. His hope and dream is to buy a pickup for transporting livestock to the nearby markets.

loans.use: to buy more goats and sheep for selling.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a thirty-five years-old married man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. After realising the lucrative nature of the produce business, he decided to venture into maize sales and he has been able to reap a lot of profits. Like all good fathers, Juluis dreams of seeing his children graduating with degrees and having good paying jobs.

He has the hardship of price fluctuation and high transportation costs from the farmers to the market due to a poor road network. His ambition is to diversify into home use products since the produce  business has peak and off seasons. Julius is requesting for a loan to buy maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy limestone to sell.

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 35-year-old married man and a father of one child. He lives and works in Nabatieh, where he raises chicks in a very professional way. Husein loves his business a lot and works on improving it to keep it producing good quality merchandise to sell.

Husein applied for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, in order to build a food chamber for his chicks and to  buy  fans for the summer season, and heaters for the winter.

This is Husein's fourth cycle as Al Majmoua borrower with a good standing in paying back his previous loans. His previous loans helped him a lot in improving his social and financial situations. Husein is very optimistic about this loan and he is very sure that it will improve his family's living.

loans.use: to build a food chamber for his chicks.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is a 63-year-old married woman with a child, living in Clarin, Misamis Occidental.   Her husband is a farmer. 

In order to add income in the family, she entered into buying and selling of vegetables and some spices, which started five years ago. She usually gets PHP 5,000 per month. 

With the help of GDMPC microcredit, Francisca was able to obtain vegetables and spices to sell because of the PHP 15,000 loan to her. She joined GDMPC in 2007. 

Someday, she’s hoping for much greater revenue for business expansion.

loans.use: to obtain vegetables and spices to sell.

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en:
Dennis is 34 years old, married, with a healthy child. He is a rice grower in Annafatan and usually yields PHP 10,000 each harvest season twice a year. He would like to increase his income for his family's sustenance for food and electric bills. He is now asking for PHP 10,000 to buy insecticides and fertilizer used in farming. This will help nourish rice seedlings to grow healthier.  

Someday, he hopes to harvest more sacks of rice to sell so he can pay debts to neighbors and earn for his child's education leading to a successful life someday.

loans.use: to buy insecticides and fertilizer used in farming

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
Romel is a farmer, and he has been in this business for almost 12 years now. 

He had a hectare plot of land where he planted and harvested rice to sell.   He is now asking for additional capital of PHP 10,000 to maintain a good growth of crops with the help of fertilizers and insecticides paid for by this loan. 

Someday, he hopes to keep producing abundant harvest and invest for the studies of his children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and inseticides use in farming.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 53 years old and a mixed crop farmer.  He is married to Venasia, a farmer as well. They are blessed with four children. 

Daniel has been in the farming business for the past 12 years, with a monthly income of KES 19,000 that he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his second loan term with KADET LTD, after repaying the previous loan successfully. Daniel will use the loan to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his farm. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. His hopes and dreams are being able to buy a piece of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en: Luciana is a 52-year-old married woman who resides in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She has 3 grown children. Luciana manages a general store to support the family, earning an income of PHP 4,000. Luciana has applied for a loan of PHP 9,500 to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. She has been a member of GDMPC since 2011. Luciana plans to expand her business to gain more income.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Hamidan

texts.en:
Ms Hamidan is 45 years old and a married woman. She lives in a village of Khudian.  She has six children, and her husband is the only earner of the family. 

Her husband is in the field of agricultural activities and assists in selling milk door-to-door. Therefore she decided to help her husband in managing the household. She purchased a buffalo 10 years ago and started to sell the milk. Now she counts a good client list. With the support of her husband, she is running a successful business to lead them to a respectable life. 

She requested a loan of Rs. 20,000 to purchase one more buffalo to milk and serve more customers. She hopes to utilize the part of profit on her family's well being and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase one more buffalo to milk and serve more customers.

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en:
Carlito is very happy for his income from a farming business he has managed for over 10 years now. It serves as his family's primary source of income. He is 40 years old, married, and has children to educate. 

He grows rice to sell to traders at their village.  Now he is borrowing PHP 10,000 from our generous KIVA lenders to sustain his crops by buying urea(fertilizers) and pesticides. He will buy these farm inputs to use in his farming business. He promises to pay back his loan in full. 

He hopes to achieve an abundant harvest, so he can save funds for his children's studies.  He is hoping they will finish a degree as it is the only legacy he could pass on to them. His photo was taken during land cultivation on his ricefield.

loans.use: to buy urea (fertilizers) and pesticides used in farming

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a resident of Murang’a in Central Kenya where she lives with her family of two children. She has been in the farming business for three years and currently produces milk and tea for the local market, which helps her meet her family's basic needs.

Lucy has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a chuff cutter. This will help ease the feeding of her dairy cow and save her more time to run other family errands. Lucy is optimistic that her dairy cows will improve their milk capacity with better feeding. She will use a larger portion of her income to educate her children. Lucy says the challenge remains rampant fluctuation in milk prices.

loans.use: To buy a chuff cutter

loans.name: Nusrat

texts.en:
Ms Nusrat is a 34-year-old married woman. She has successfully run a small general store in her community for the last five years. Nusrat offers various items for everyday use. She uses her good communication skills and has a good client base. Nusrat's husband is a salesperson at a garment shop; his income is insufficient to support his family.

Nusrat is the mother of five children and she is motivated to provide for her family. Since she wants to grow her business, she has requested a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy stocks of detergents and other grocery items in large quantities to meet the increasing demand. Nusrat wishes to use part of her revenues to deal with her children’s education expenses and to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To buy stocks of detergents and other grocery items.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es: Amelia desde muy niña ya caminaba las Hermosas playas de Bocagrande en la ciudad de Cartagena, vendiendo artículos propios para ser usado en las playas, por eso aprendió de su madre a quien siempre acompañó y hoy se dedica a  la venta de ropas y calzado especialmente playero, pues vive en esta turística ciudad cercada por el Mar Caribe, donde este vestuario es un estilo requerido,  por el ambiente de playa,  brisa y mar de esta ciudad histórica, amurallada.  Amelia en su condición de mujer separada y madre de 2 niños en las edades de 5 y 7 años, trabaja muy fuertemente, porque sueña verlos convertidos en profesionales exitosos y ellos son su motor en su desempeño como comerciante. Amelia vende suéteres, blusas, pantalonetas, calzado y artículos a clientes ocasionales y fijos que usualmente le solicitan estas mercancías  y que ella logra comprar  en la ciudad de Barranquilla, cuando recupera su capital  de trabajo, cuya  mayor proporción  está representado entre sus cuentas por cobrar.  Sus principales clientes los encuentra en las playas de Cartagena y de Barranquilla y son en su mayoría turistas, que usualmente buscan las opciones de ropa que Amelia ofrece. Sus ventas las realiza diariamente desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde, mientras sus compras las realiza de contado y semanalmente en sitios donde hay promociones constantes, y ofertas de saldos que son conveniente para ella y especialmente para su clientela. Su meta mas adelante es tener su propia casa trabajando mucho para ahorrar y en el futuro lograrlo. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa playera que son los artículos que rotan mayormente entre sus clientes fijos y con los cuales ampliará el volumen de sus ventas, para ganar cada vez mas y beneficiar los ingresos de su familia especialmente de sus hijos.
texts.en:
From a young age, Amelia has walked the beautiful beaches of Bocagrande in the city of Cartagena selling beach items. She learned this skill from her mother, who always accompanied her. Today, she sells clothing and shoes, especially for the beach since she lives in a tourist city near the Caribbean Sea. This type of clothing is needed here due to the atmosphere of the beach, the breeze, and the sea by this historic, fortified city.

Amelia is currently separated and is a mother of two children ages 5 and 7. She works hard because she dreams of seeing her children as successful professionals. They are her motivation to work hard as a merchant.

Amelia sells sweaters, blouses, shorts, shoes and other items to new and regular customers who request this merchandise, which she buys in the city of Barranquilla when she recoups her working capital. The majority of this capital comes from her accounts receivable. Her main customers are found on the beaches of Cartagena and Barranquilla, and they are mainly tourists looking for the clothing options that Amelia offers. She sells from 8am until 5pm and her purchases are made weekly in cash at places that have constant promotions and sales that are convenient for her, and especially for her customers. In the future, her goal is to have her own home by working a lot and saving for this accomplishment. She is currently applying for a Kiva loan and this is the first time she will receive financing from the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. She will buy beach clothing with the loan, which is the most popular among her regular customers. This will increase her sales volume and earn more profits, which will benefit her family and especially her children.

loans.use: to buy beach clothing to sell.

loans.name: Zafran

texts.en:
Zafran is a 31-year-old married, vigorous lady. She is a dedicated mother of two children and has been running a general store for the last 10 years. According to Zafran, she faced many problems during her early married life. Her husband is a labor person. He was not able to cover the expenses of her family alone. She took the initiative to start her business by taking a loan from Kashf foundation 10 years ago and made a small general store near her house.  

By this time, she is very much satisfied and requested a repeat loan of PKR 20000 to buy rice and flour to meet her customers’ demands time after time. She wishes to utilize part of the revenue for her children’s well-being and education.

loans.use: To buy rice and flour to meet her customers’ demands time after time.

loans.name: Ma. Merlinda

texts.en:
Ma. Merlinda is a 35-year-old farmer from Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. She has been in the farming business for more than ten years now. Her husband works as a carpenter.

Ma. Merlinda grows different kinds of crops in their field. She also raises pigs and a cow.

Ma. Merlinda needs additional funds for the business. She is asking for a loan worth 8000 PHP to buy fertilizer for the plants and to buy additional pigs to raise. With this, she will be able to produce a good harvest from the field thus giving her more of a chance to sell good quality crops to the market.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for the plants and additional pigs to raise.

loans.name: Oeurn's Group

texts.en:
Oeurn is a farmer from a rural area of Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been farming rice for over thirty years to support their family of two children. To earn additional income for the family, they both grow vegetables for sale. 

This will be Oeurn's second loan with VisionFund. The first loan enabled her to better feed her family. Given her good performance, Oeurn was appointed to be the leader of her group of five female members. Oeurn will use her portion of this loan to buy fertilizers, seedlings and pesticides for her rice and vegetable farm. She hopes the crops will produce a good yield so that she can sell the products for good money and, as a result, get a proper house for her family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds and pesticides for her plantation

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 6 children. For the past 7 years, Elizabeth has operated a sari-sari (variety) store, buying and selling canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. Elizabeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned good, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en: Reynaldo, 50 years old, is married to Myrna. He is a farmer who grows rice to sell to traders. Reynaldo pays additional laborers to help him with the farming activities (sowing, tilling, planting and harvesting). He usually gains PHP 10,000 each harvest season (twice a year), which is used for the family's meals and his child's school fees. Reynaldo is now asking for a loan of PHP 10,00 to enure healthy crops to harvest profitably. In the future, Reynaldo would like to become a successful rice grower for the development of the family's poor living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seeds

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali, 26 years old, is married and the father of one child. He is a hard worker who puts much effort into improving his business to improve his family's living conditions. Ali works hard to provide his child with the best life and education ever. He started working 10 years ago, when he was 16 years old, to cover his own expenses and help his family.

Ali works as a house painter. In 2010, he started his own business to improve his income and expand his business. Ali has applied for a YOUTH LOAN from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, in order to buy a new Renault rapid car, necessary to transport his tools from one place to another. This car will improve and ease Ali's business a lot because he will be capable of moving his tools from one place to another in a short period of time. He can also use the car as the tools' mobile warehouse. Ali is very proud of the level he has reached in his business and hopes to keep on improving it, to provide his family with the best living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a new car to transport his tools from one job to another

loans.name: Flamboyan I Group

texts.en:
Since 2007, women's self-help groups already have been running. Flamboyan I is the name of this group of 14 members, located in a small suburb called Kroya. There are various types of businesses in this group, especially selling traditional foods such as egg rolls, arem-arem, wet pastel, gethuk lindri, tendril Gesing, and nagasari. There is also a business selling clothes. The members are very closely intertwined in solidarity because they co-exist and complement one another's types of snack foods while getting orders. They meet every month, taking turns hosting the meeting at each member's home. Some plans for this loan are to buy better means of production, and to buy more sophisticated cake molds in order to produce cakes more quickly.

Titi is the leader of this group and she is remarkable because she gives encouragement to other members. She has a small business making food such as wet pastel, dry pastel, and egg rolls. The benefits of the loan from Kiva are very meaningful to her life with her husband and two children. Their relationship is getting warmer because all of her work was done along with her husband. Titi hopes that with the help, she can buy additional tools to increase her production of printed cakes. Also, every member of the Flamboyan group and their families can prosper. In the picture, Titi is holding some goods she has produced.

loans.use: to buy additional equipment for making cakes

loans.name: Hanifa

texts.en:
Ms. Hanifa is a 54-year-old married woman. She is an active lady and has three buffalo in milk. She started milk sales ten years ago for the sake of her family. She has a good number of customers which are increasing gradually. Her business is good enough to provide her with a decent life. 

She is the mother of seven children. She lives in a large conventional family with her husband, children, and other relatives. Her husband is employed in a small general store as a sales person. She requires earning more to cover the everyday expenditures of her family.  

Now she requested a loan amount of Rs. 20,000. She will be using the loan to buy one more buffalo to inflate milk sales. She expects an increase in her business income. She intends to utilize the earned profits for providing good and quality food to her family members.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo to inflate milk sales.

loans.name: Luis Osvaldo

texts.es: El Señor Osvaldo tiene 29 años de edad vive en Chimoré del departamento de Cochabamba es plomero de profesión y los del lugar lo contratan constantemente. Osvaldo es una persona sencilla y siempre estuvo acostumbrado a la labor del campo, en un tiempo atrás Osvaldo se dedico mucho a la bebida y perdió todo lo que consiguió sus amigos lo echaron a perder y cuando mas necesitaba ayuda para poder seguir trabajando estos amigos no aparecieron es así que Osvaldo aprendió a no fiarse de los demás, ahora él vive solo para su familia y se dedica a trabajo íntegramente con la finalidad de no volver a tropezar con amistades que desestabilicen su bienestar, esta ahorrando para poder realizar una construcción sencilla en su lote para comodidad de su familia y al enterarse de los créditos Kiva él solicita una ayuda para poder dar un capital para la compra de pollos para la venta, ella también pueda generar ingresos, su sueño es ver que sus hijos terminen el colegio y se encaminen en estudios superiores para su propio beneficio.
texts.en:
Osvaldo is 29 years old and lives in Chimoré, department of Cochabamba. He is a plumber by profession and people from his city hire him constantly. Osvaldo is a modest person, and he was always used to work the land. 

A while ago, Osvaldo used to drink a lot and he lost all he had. His friends spoiled him and when he needed help to continue working these friends did not appear. That's how Osvaldo learned to be wary of others. Now he lives only for his family and is entirely dedicated to work in order to not bump into friends that destabilize his welfare. He is saving to make a modest construction in his plot for his family's comfort.

He heard about Kiva loans and decided to request help to provide capital for the purchase of chickens for sale. He wants to generate income, his dream is to see his children finish school and pursue higher education for their own benefit.

loans.use: to buy chickens (dead) for commercialization

loans.name: Wafa'a

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Wafa'a prefers that her photo is not on the Internet; thus the above photo is of her husband. 

Wafa'a is a 27-year-old married woman who has one family member from Bani Kenanah, Irbid, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to pay for her home improvements. She would like to buy household items and she wants to repaint the rooms. 

In the future, she hopes to provide for her family a good environment to live in.

Since Wafa'a is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is a 54-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in the fishing business for five years since her husband works as a fisherman. This is their source of income which they use for the family's daily needs and expenses. Estelita gives her best to support her husband.

Estelita joined CEVI because she likes the services offered by the organization, such as loans, insurance and training. She is requesting a loan of 10.000 PHP to buy new fishing nets and fuel for the fishing boat. In the future, Estelita wants to expand their current business and to invest in other ventures to augment their income.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and fuel for the fishing boat

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Rima is a 46-year-old Lebanese single woman living alone. She’s facing bad financial conditions, especially after her family’s nonexistence next to her. 

In 2004, she started to work as a beautician. She works from home and also visits customers wherever they are located to provide them with her high-quality beauty services. 

Today, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a laser machine so that she can improve her business operations and follow up on the new fashion. This is her first Kiva loan and she is very thankful for the results attained so far. 

The demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high and that is a good chance for Rima to enlarge her business and maybe hire more employees to help her with her job.

loans.use: to purchase a laser machine.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en: Belinda sells barbecued food in her community so as to support her daily needs. She has been in this business for 3 years. She earns 7,000 PHP each month from these activities. Belinda, single, is 36 years old and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Belinda has requested a loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC to purchase raw ingredients to barbecue and to purchase kitchen utensils for food preparation. She's a new member of GDMPC. In the future, Belinda hopes to expand her barbecue vending and have a stall in the city for food vending.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to barbecue and to purchase kitchen utensils for food preparation

loans.name: Safa'a

texts.en: Safa'a is a 39-year-old married woman who supports 3 family members. She is from Jubeiha, Amman, Jordan. Safa'a is requesting a loan of 1,000 JOD to pay for home improvements; she would like to buy new furniture and to do maintenance of the rooms. In the future, Safa'a hopes to buy a new home and to provide her family with a good environment to live in.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan, 18 years old, is single and lives with his parents and two siblings, one of whom works. Hasan’s father is responsible for covering his family’s demands and, above all, enhancing their way of living. In order to help his father, Hasan decided to start his own business at an early age. He works as a car electrician and has his own garage. He has gained good experience, which has helped him attract added clients.

Hasan is asking for a youth loan from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase needed electrical supplies for his business. The loan will enable him to facilitate his business and receive more than one car at a time. Hasan is an ambitious man who always seeks to improve his family’s life by better developing his work.

loans.use: to purchase needed electrical supplies for his business

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad, 28 years old, lives with his wife and two children, both still attending school. After gaining eight years of experience in his present occupation, Ahmad was able to open his own barbershop. Due to his good business reputation, he has built a good career with a fair number of loyal customers. In parallel, he has four years of experience working at “Electricité du Liban”.

Ahmad will use his requested youth loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase shaving tools. supplies and a chair. The loan will enable him to satisfy his customers’ demands and serve them at the top. Ahmad seeks to expand his business and focus on one profession to better support his family.

loans.use: to purchase shaving tools, supplies and a chair

loans.name: Catalino

texts.en: Catalino, a generous father, and his wife, Edna, have managed a farming business for almost eight years. They usually gain PHP 10,000 each harvest season (twice a year), which is used for meals, monthly electric bills and their four children's education. Catalino would like to increase his farming income  but he has insufficient funds. Therefore, he is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy rice seeds and to pay for laborers for transplanting. Catalino needs to hire laborers because he is not capable of doing all the farming activities such as sowing, tilling and transplanting rice seedlings. In the future, Catalino would like to ensure a good harvest in his rice field for the overall development of his business and his family, as well.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and to pay for laborers

loans.name: Tahani

texts.en: Tahani is a 38-year-old married woman from Bani Kenanah, Irbid, Jordan who supports 7 family members. She is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to pay for her home improvements. She will be repainting her home. She would like in the future to improve her family's socioeconomic status.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en: Lilibeth is 21 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 1 child. For the past 3 years, Lilibeth has operated a sari-sari (variety) store, buying and selling canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products and beverages. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages. Lilibeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business for the education of her child.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
This is Marcelina, 56. She is resident of Taguig, Philippines. She is married to Roberto, self-employed and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marcelina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 32,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marcelina hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
This is Jonathan. He previously obtained a 10,000 PHP loan that he used to buy more quantities of fish and meat products. His earnings were a big help in meeting his personal, household, and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy more quantities of fish and meat products needed in her business. He also has a junk shop business. His profits from business will definitely help him to sustain his daily, personal and business needs. 

He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. 

Jonathan hopes his business grows more in the coming years. He faithfully meets every week with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of ther work.  It is where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in his business.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma. She previously accessed a 22,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan that she used to purchase larger quantities and varieties of merchandise like herbal products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 22,000 PHP loan to buy additional stock of herbal products like herbal coffee,supplements and tea needed in her business. The more items displayed in the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to meet her daily needs and cover the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Norma hopes to expand soon, and she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of coffee and herbal products needed in her business

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
This is Emelia, who previously accessed an 21,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of slippers and other merchandise needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy additional stocks of clothes and merchandise needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to cover her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Emelia hopes to expand her business in the coming year and give her children a high-quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories about her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who meet to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy slippers and other products for her business

loans.name: Melania

texts.en:
This is Melania, 42, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Antonio, a sewer, and is a mother to her child. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Melania maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Melania hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of having a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise needed in her business

loans.name: Ehtiram

texts.en:
Ehtiram is a 33-year-old married woman, the mother of two kids. They live in a rented home. 

She has a fruits and vegetable store that provides the family with another source of income.  That’s why she is planning on expanding it by adding more kinds of fruits and vegetables to increase their profits, so she can help her husband in household bills.  For that, she applied for this loan.

loans.use: to add more kinds of fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Pasencia

texts.en:
This is Pasencia, 40, resident of Manila, Philippines. She is the mother of four children. She, together with her children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Pacencia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 19,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Pasencia hopes to grow her business and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Alvaro

texts.es: El Señor Alvaro tiene 36 años de edad vive en el municipio de Chimoré del departamento de Cochabamba es ingeniero y vive del trabajo de sus servicios prestados en especial de gran magnitud. Alvaro es una persona sencilla y siempre estuvo acostumbrado a la labor del campo, no le fue bien al comienzo de la aplicación de su profesión ya que sostuvo varios contratiempos y fraudes por parte de empresas que lo utilizaron y no le pagaron lo que acordaban en sus contratos así tuvo que aprender y de esa experiencia sacar provecho de lo mas bueno aprendido, ahora el esta repuesto y se dedica a una obra de gran envergadura, se entero de los créditos Kiva por lo que solicita y así poder comprara un lote en el lugar donde trabaja para poder establecerse sin tener que acudir a la ayuda de ajenos, el sueña con tener una vida plena con algunos ahorros para formalizar una familia y tener días mejores gracias al esfuerzo de su actual trabajo.
texts.en: Alvaro is 36 years old and lives in the municipality of Chimore in the province of Cochabamba.  He is an engineer and supports himself by providing services especially on a large scale.  Alvaro is a simple person and has always been accustomed to working in the country.  His start in his profession did not go well as he had numerous setbacks and frauds on the part of companies who used him and then did not pay him in accordance with their contracts.  Thus he had to learn from this experience to make the most of things.  Now he has recovered, and is dedicating himself to a work of great scope.  He heard about Kiva loans and therefore is requesting one to be able to buy a plot of land in order to establish himself without needing help from others.  His dream is to have a full life with some savings in order to begin a family and have better days due to his own hard work.

loans.use: To buy land.

loans.name: Kelle Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe issu du Banc Villageois Kelle est créé le 30 décembre 2009. Il est composé de 13 femmes qui habitent le même village et sont en bonne entente.

Dado la présidente de ce groupe,est une femme de 32 ans, mariée et mère de 04 enfants dont 03 filles et 01 garçon.Elle fait de l'embouche depuis plus d'un an. Elle achète ses sujets au marché hebdomadaire. Sur la photo, elle est debout tout à fait à droite et porte l'enfant. 

Avec son prêt elle voudrai acheter 02 moutons ou bien 01 mouton et 01 chèvre pour embouche. 

Avec ses bénéfices, elle a la prise en charge de sa famille car son mari a une autre famille à Dakar.
texts.en:
This group, which stems from the Kelle Banc Villageois, was created on December 30, 2009.  It comprises 13 women who live in the same village and get along well with each other.

Dado is the group's leader.  She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of four children (three girls and one boy).  She has been involved in fattening livestock for more than one year.  She buys her livestock at the weekly market.  In the photo, she is the woman standing at the far right, carrying a child.

She plans to use her loan to buy a couple of sheep - or one sheep and one goat - and to fatten them up.

She will use her profits to support her family, since her husband has another family in Dakar.

loans.use: to buy livestock for her business.

loans.name: Jennelyn

texts.en:
This is Jennelyn, 25, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines.    Single, she is working hard to continually provide income for  everyday expenses.  

Jennelyn operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell them with a little profit. 

Her products are men's and women’s clothes and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy because of the low selling prices and the many options she offers.   Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy ready-to-wear products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Jennelyn hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and draw her family more closely to God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week.  It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to repair the engines in his workshop.

loans.name: Mibanda Group

texts.fr:
Honorine fait partie du groupe  Mibanda et  habite à Rumonge. Elle a 30 ans et est mariée à Eric, commerçant des habits et des chaussures. Ensemble ils ont 3 enfants, âgés de 2 à 9ans, dont 2 étudient.
Elle prend  soin d’un orphelin.

Elle fait le commerce des habits et des chaussures neuves  depuis  1 an. 

C’est son premier  crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  beaucoup de chaussures et des habits, à revendre, pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une parcelle et y construire une maison. Elle voudrait en outre voir ses enfants aller à l’école.  .
texts.en:
Honorine is a member of the Mibanda group and she lives in Rumonge.  She is 30 years old and married to Eric, who sells clothes and shoes.  They have three children together, ages 2 to 9 years old.  Two of their children are in school.  Honorine also takes care of one orphan.

She has been selling clothes and new shoes for one year.

This is Honorine's first loan with Turame.  With her Kiva loan, she will increase her capital and buy a large quantity of shoes and clothes for resale, in order to make more money.

In the coming years, she would like to buy a plot of land and build a house.  She would also like to see her children go to school.

loans.use: to increase her capital and buy a large quantity of shoes and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
La socia es la señora Nancy, ahora tiene 41 años de edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos,  vive en el distrito de Tambo Real, la socia se sigue dedicando a la   elaboración de productos lácteos como queso y yogurt, además de esto, ella también se dedica a la crianza de animales menores como cuyes y gallinas.
Nancy necesita elaborar más queso y yogurt, por ello invertirá su préstamo solicitado en  comprar leche para la fabricación del queso y del yogurt.
La socia está muy agradecida con KIVA por ayudarla a desarrollarse en su actividad y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas. Nancy pertenece al banco comunal “San Bartolo de Tambo Real” distrito de Tambo Real de la provincia de Anta en Cusco – Perú.
Nancy quiere proporcionarles una mejor vida y educación a sus hijos,  y por ellos se sacrifica, así que espera trabajar mucho y ahorrar para invertir en la educación de ellos.
texts.en: The partner is Nancy, who is 41 years old and is married with 4 children.  She lives in the district of Tambo Real.  She works making dairy products such as cheese and yogurt, and in addition to this raises small animals such as guinea pigs and chickens.  Nancy needs to produce more cheese and yogurt, and thus will invest the loan she is requesting to buy milk to produce cheese and yogurt.  She is very grateful to KIVA for helping her with this activity and commits to making her loan repayments.  Nancy belongs to the "San Bartolo de Tambo Real" communal bank in the Tambo Real district in the province of Anta de Cusco, Peru.  Nancy wants to provide a better life and education for her children, and for this she makes sacrifices.  She plans to work hard and save to invest in their education.

loans.use: to buy milk to make cheese and yogurt.

loans.name: Maa Gangadi Group

texts.en:
Sasmita, the featured member, is sitting on the extreme left with her hand raised in the photo. She is a young lady of 25 years who resides in the village of Thakpali in the Khariar block in the Nuapada district of Odisha, India. She has formed a group named Maa Gangadi (an adorned deity of the locality) consisting of five members of the same village. Sasmita’s family is comprised of five members: her husband and three daughters who are seven years old, three years.old, and 6 months old. She hails from a Below Poverty Line family. (BPL). Her elder daughter is studying in the second standard. Though her husband has a small piece of land that can be cultivated, due to financial scarcity, he was not farm able to cultivate the land and was forced to do the business of supplying dry food items like snacks, tea, mixture etc. by bike and selling in the nearby villages. To add to this, her husband has completed graduation but due to bad luck, he failed to get a job. 

Sasmita has been running an incense stick making business at her home for the last four years. Her husband goes to a wholesale market 200 km away once a week to bring home raw materials like raw sticks. She was impressed and preferred to start the business to add some income to her family. To cater to the educational expenses of her children, she intends to increase her income. With the present loan, Sasmita wants to maintain raw materials like raw sticks, perfumes, chemicals etc. for one month so that she can save time, money and energy, which can be otherwise used in productive work. Within this period, she will prepare and sell her product in bulk quantity. Sasmita has a long desire to educate her daughters in a better school for a better future, and construct a house for her residence and business, thereby improving her living conditions.

Saratmanjari, Tulasilata, Bandana and Maharagi are the other four members of the group. They are running a cloth business, a milk business, a grocery shop and a footwear business, respectively.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, raw sticks etc.

loans.name: Marybeth

texts.en:
Marybeth is 40 years old and lives in Taguig, Philippines. She is married, the mother of several children and works hard to earn enough money to meet everyday expenses. She earns a living by buying men and women’s clothes from wholesalers and selling them in retail markets. Her customers like her low prices and wide selection of items for sale. Most people who buy her clothing are neighbors.  She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) every day. To help expand her business, she is applying for a loan for PHP 20,000. She will use this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers and enlarge the size of her inventory. She expects this loan to boost her business. Her goal for the future is to buy her own land and house. She faithfully meets up with fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and draw strength from her religion.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 people who meet to study religion, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Ma. Nena

texts.en:
This is Ma. Nena, 55, who is a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Edgardo and has children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma. Nena operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Ma. Nena hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group

texts.en:
In 2010, four women from Bhuliasikuan village located in the Khariar block of Nuapada district, one of the poorest regions in India, stepped out and decided to build a secure future for their family by sharing the burden of the family with their husbands. They formed a group named Maa Mangala (named after a Hindu goddess).Chanchala is standing to the extreme left in the photo. She is 40 years and lives with her husband, father in-law and mother in-law. Chanchala hails from a Below Poverty Line family. For the last 20 years, Chanchala has been running a cloth weaving business with her husband. She has one weaving set. Her husband purchases the yarn/thread for weaving saris from a trader in a village 20 kms away. A bundle of thread produces 80-100 pieces of saris and costs around 10,000-15,000 rupees. Chanchala does the initial processing of the thread to make it ready for weaving. After that, her husband fits it to the weaving machine and starts the weaving work. Chanchala’s husband works around 8-10 hours a day and weaves a single piece of sari.  On a weekly basis, Chanchala sells saris to the local traders in her village. She earns a monthly income of Rs 3, 000, which is not sufficient to maintain her family. Chanchala wants to buy thread/yarn in bulk with the loan. Purchasing more stock at one time will help her to reduce the purchasing cost of the raw materials. Chanchala wants to increase her business and save enough to complete the construction of her house.

Upama, Ujal and Bhanumati are the three other members of the group who are running a general grocery shop and a cloth weaving business, and getting support from their husbands for the over all development of their families.

loans.use: to purchase yarn.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
This is Magdalena, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Pacifico and has children. She manages the household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Magdalena operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a Php50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Magdalena hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma, 56, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Ronnie and has a child. She and her husband manages their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Norma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. Norma hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Yaneth Del Socorro

texts.es: Yaneth con su anterior credikiva compró insumos para prepara las comidas en su restaurante y ganó descuentos por su compra de contado y en mayor volumen. También su credikiva le alcanzó para comprar sillas, mesas, y artículos que habían pedido sus clientes como ropa infantil pues está iniciando una nueva actividad, con la cual planea aprovechar el mercado de su restaurante que es fijo y proveerles las mercancías variadas que su familia requiere. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un nuevo credikiva con el que invertirá en ropa y surtirá su tenderete, para dar satisfacción al mercado y para ella poder generar un poco mas de ingresos. Ella envía un mensaje de agradecimiento  a los financiadores de Kiva y es el siguiente: “Les agradezco mucho, ojalá me sigan apoyando a mi y a otros microempresarios.“
texts.en: With her last Kiva loan Yaneth bought supplies to make food for her restaurant, and obtained discounts by paying cash and buying in bulk.  Her loan was also enough for her to buy chairs, tables and items that her customers had asked her for such as children's clothing.  She is starting a new business, with which she plans to take advantage of the customer base of her restaurant, which is steady, and provide them with items that they require for their families. For this reason she is requesting a new Kiva loan, which she will invest in clothing and supply her clothing stall, in order to satisfy her customers and earn more income.  She sends the following message of gratitude to Kiva lenders: "I thank you very much, and hope you will continue supporting me and other microbusiness owners".

loans.use: to buy clothing and supply her clothing stall, in order to satisfy her customers.

loans.name: Sedjro Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres exercent leurs activités dans la même zone. Le représentant du groupe, Adandé Jules (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgé de 28 ans et est un célibataire. Adandé Jules a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Adandé Jules vit seul et assure seul ses divers besoins. Pour ce faire, il y a près de trois ans que Adandé Jules mène comme activité la vente des céréales (maïs, sorgho) dans sa région. Adandé Jules s’approvisionne dans une région du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Adandé Jules sollicite un premier crédit ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe SEDJRO. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The Sedjro group is composed of three members working in the same zone. The group’s representative, Adandé Jules (the one raising his hand in the photo) is 28 years old and single. Adandé Jules has left school at the secondary level. Adandé Jules lives alone and supports himself. In order to do so, he has been selling cereals (corn, sorghum) in his region for three years. He stocks up in a region of Benin. With the goal of meeting customer demand, Adandé Jules, together with the other members of the Sedjro group, is seeking his first loan. This loan will allow the group members to better meet demand and to increase their revenues.

loans.use: to buy cereals (corn, sorghum).

loans.name: Radha Krushna Group

texts.en:
This group formed in the year 2009 and is called “Radha Krushna” (named after the Hindu Lord Krishna and His power). It is a group comprised of four women members of the village called Dumerbahal. It is located in the Nuapada district; one of the poorest districts of India. One of the members of this group is Dibyarani who has raised her hand in the photo. She is 26 years old and her family consists of her husband, one small daughter, father in-law and mother in-law. Dibyarani has been running a small bakery factory in her house with the help of her husband for the last 12 years. In the factory, bakery items like bread, cream roll and toast etc. are being prepared. She has engaged four skilled laborers for the processing and making of the bakery items. Her husband supplies the products to three or four nearby towns within a 40 km radius. Dibyarani says owing to better quality, design, packing and forms of her products, there is a lot of demand from the locals, but due to a shortage of stock she could not meet their demands. She does not like to say “No” to her customers and wants to give better service to her customers. She now wants to buy more stock of oil, dough, etc. to increase her production level to meet the demands and grab her customers. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase raw materials in bulk, which will reduce her purchasing and transportation costs. As the present location of the factory is in her residence, Dibyarani wants to construct a separate house in a prominent place in her locality to run the business smoothly. She also hopes to save money from the sale proceeds for provide a better education facility to her only girl child.

The other three active members of the group are Nabina, who has a sweets-making business and grocery shop, Jajnaseni, who sells and supplies bakery items, and Rangalata who has a grocery business and hopes to provide better education to their children and increase their living standard.

loans.use: to purchase oil, dough, sugar etc.

loans.name: Orokia's Group

texts.fr:
Mme OROKIA représente le groupe DIOUGOU SOMPRIN. Elle se porte bien ainsi que tout le groupe. Mariée, elle est mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 15ans et le moins âgé a 12ans. Tous vont à l’école et elle a 04 personnes en charge.

Mme vend habits et oignons depuis 10ans. Son prêt s’est bien déroulé. Elle s’approvisionne à Gounra (Lanfiara) frontière Tiébélé. Ses clients sont hommes et femmes.

Mme veut s’acheter 15sacs d’oignons et 20complet pagnes.

Avec ses économies, elle veut aider  à la scolarisation des enfants et épargner. Elle tient toujours son ambition  d’ouvrir un magasin.
texts.en:
Orokia is the representative of the DIOUGOU SOMPRIN group.  She is doing well, and so are the other members of the group.  She is married and the mother of two children, ages 15 and 12, who both go to school.  Orokia has four people in her care.

Orokia has been selling clothes and onions for ten years.  There has been no problem with her loan.  

Orokia buys her goods in Gounra (Lanfiara), near Tiébélé, and she sells to both men and women.

She wants to buy 15 bags of onions and 20 "pagnes" (colorful West-African fabrics), measuring 1 x 3 meters each.

She wants to use her savings to contribute to her children's education.  She also wants to continue to save some money.  Her ambition is still to open a shop.

loans.use: to buy 15 bags of onions and 20 "pagnes" (measuring 1 x 3 meters each).

loans.name: Maa Laxmi Group

texts.en:
This group is called Maa Laxmi (named after the Hindu Goddess of wealth). Its five members are all women who belong to the Below Poverty Line category (BPL) from the village called Gadramunda. It is located in the block of Khariar of Nuapada district of Odisha, one of the poorest districts in India, specially known for drought. Among the five members is Panchu. The lady sitting in the middle raising her hand is Panchu. She is 29 years old; living with her husband, three sons aged 10, 8 & 5 years and one daughter who is 2 years old. She is a very active lady and fond of cooking. She has been running a snacks & sweets-making and supply business at her house with the help of her husband for a couple of years. She initially started with two varieties and slowly expanded to three different varieties. She, along with her husband, cook local salty snacks named 'Namkin' (locally popular food of triangular shape and salty in taste), “Gaja” (fried dough dipped in sugar syrup) & Ladduu (one type of round shaped sweet) and make packages. Her husband travels to the surrounding villages selling to local shops there. He travels almost 40 km in a day. She and her husband spend almost four hours a day making snacks and packets and selling them.  In this process, her family earns a profit of rupees 200/- to 250/- daily. For raw materials like cooking oil, sugar and dough, her husband travels to the nearby town frequently every three days and spend more time and transportation cost. She now wants to have a stock of raw materials like cooking oil, sugar and dough, so that they have enough stock to carry on their business regularly with out any intervention. Panchu has planned to use a portion of the loan to buy the raw materials in bulk, saving the transportation cost and getting a cash discount. She hopes to complete her half-built house and start a screen printing business as her husband has sufficient experience in that field by using the rest of her loan. 

The other four members of the group are Sasirekha, Jachana, Pana and Suraj and they have businesses like selling milk, running a grocery shop and cultivating vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase dough, sugar, oil etc

loans.name: Maa Maheswari Group

texts.en:
The name of this group is Maa Maheswari (named after a village deity of the locality). All four women members of this group belong to Kurebhana village in Bolangir district in Odisha, India and are in the BPL (Below Poverty Line) category.  People from the BPL category live on less than one dollar a day. Saila, sitting in the middle with her hand raised in the photo, is one of the members of this group. She is 40 years old and lives with her husband, two daughters who are 17 and 15 years old and a son who is 19 years old.
 
Saila’s husband is landless. He does daily labor and earn a very small income. Saila runs a milk processing unit at her house. She has only one cow, which produces 8 to 10 liters of milk per day. As the milk is not sufficient, Saila and her husband go to three or four nearby villages and collect 200 liters of milk per day to process and produce milk products like Paneer, Chhena (cheese), butter, ghee, khua and Peda (a sweet item made of khua) and sell them to earn an income of Rs 400 to Rs 500 per day in the off season (August-October). In the peak season, i.e. in the marriage season, (November-July) they earn Rs 1,000 to Rs 1,500 per day by selling the milk products. She employs a person to help her in the processing. She has a small freezer to keep the products and supply in the market but it is insufficient for her. With the loan, she is planning to purchase a deep freezer of 1500 kgs capacity to store the milk products for days together and sell them at peak time to earn more profit. In addition, she has a plan to construct a cement kiln for her processing unit. At present, she is educating her children in the nearby high school and college. As providing college education is very expensive,  she is trying to increase her income to meet the demands of her children. She has another plan to construct a house, as the present house is crowded..   

The other three members of her group (Jayanti, Sanjukta & Kahara) are running grocery shops and a milk business, respectively.

loans.use: to purchase a deep freezer and build a kiln.

loans.name: Vangie

texts.en:
This is Vangie, 40, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Christopher, an electrician, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Vangie operates a food stall. She sells some snack foods like banana cue and glazed sweet potatoes. Basically, these are just banana and sweet potato that are being cooked with sugar in boiling oil. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20, 000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of products like banana, sweet potato, sugar and oil. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Vangie dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:

She, together with her husband, manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Guillerma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.
